flashcards.definition: Mode of nutrition in which organisms can synthesize their own food from simple inorganic substances like CO₂ and water using sunlight energy.
The process by which green plants make their own food using carbon dioxide, water, and sunlight energy in the presence of chlorophyll.
Green pigment present in chloroplasts that absorbs light energy and is essential for photosynthesis.
Tiny pores present on the surface of leaves that allow exchange of gases (CO₂ in, O₂ out) and help in transpiration.
Specialized cells surrounding each stoma that control its opening and closing based on water content and light.
Cell organelle containing chlorophyll where photosynthesis takes place in plant cells.
Mode of nutrition in which organisms cannot make their own food and depend on other organisms for nutrition.
Plants that obtain food from other living organisms (hosts) without benefiting them. Example: Cuscuta (Dodder).
Plants that trap and digest insects to obtain nitrogen and other nutrients. Examples: Pitcher plant, Venus flytrap.
Mode of nutrition in which organisms obtain food from dead and decaying organic matter. Examples: Fungi, bacteria.
Relationship between two different organisms living in close association where both organisms benefit from each other.
Symbiotic association between algae (provides food through photosynthesis) and fungi (provides shelter and moisture).
Nitrogen-fixing bacteria that live in root nodules of leguminous plants, converting atmospheric nitrogen into usable nitrates.
Process of converting atmospheric nitrogen (N₂) into nitrogen compounds like ammonia and nitrates that plants can use.
Loss of water in the form of water vapor from the aerial parts of the plant, mainly through stomata.
Carbon dioxide (from air through stomata) and water (from soil through roots) are the two main raw materials.
Glucose (C₆H₁₂O₆) which is stored as starch, and oxygen (O₂) which is released into the atmosphere.
6CO₂ + 6H₂O + Light Energy → C₆H₁₂O₆ + 6O₂ (in presence of chlorophyll)
Plants belonging to the legume family that have root nodules containing nitrogen-fixing bacteria. Examples: Peas, beans, pulses.
Iodine test used to detect the presence of starch in leaves, confirming that photosynthesis has occurred. Starch turns blue-black with iodine.
